messages.message: You're looking at: https://github.com/instabase/instabase/blob/master/shared-utils/py-utils/ocr-client-lib/src/py/instabase/ocr/client/libs/ocr_types.py#L48. That's the list of all words which were found on a page by the OCR (or PDF) engine

just to confirm, the individual words are listed indexes 1 -> N, index 0 contains an ordered, combined string of all words found on the page. So if a PDF says “the cat ran from the dog”, [0] = “the cat ran from the dog”, [1] = “the”, [2] = “cat”, [3] = “ran”, etc.?
regarding index 0, i believe that's true. please empirically test and add a comment to that structure, but yes that is what I remember the format being
cool, yes that’s what I see as well so I believe it does hold.

i am guessing the indexes 1 -> N are ordered by pixel location from top to bottom and left to right, so if the document looks like
```
The cat ran from the dog. 
blah blah blah. 
```
Then the order is what you wrote.

But if the document looks like
```
The cat ran                           blah blah
from the dog.                         blah 
```
Then the order might be
[1] = the, [2] = cat, [3] = ran, [4] = blah, [5] = blah, [6] = from, [7] = the….
ah yes — i didn’t mean to make guarantees about word order indexes [1] -> [N], but that’s good to know.
